conclusion: Determine the resultant Ampere force on the equilateral triangular conductor frame when a constant voltage is applied across points A and B.
The equilateral triangle ABC is made of uniform resistance wires.
The resistance of each side of the triangle is the same, denoted as R.
The current will split at point A and recombine at point B.

premise: The resistance between A and B directly (AB) is R. The resistance between A and B via C (AC + CB) is 2R.
conclusion: The effective resistance between A and B is R_eff = 2R/3.

premise: The total current supplied by the power source is I.
conclusion: The current through AB is I_AB = (2/3)I.

premise: The total current supplied by the power source is I.
conclusion: The current through AC and CB is I_AC = I_CB = (1/3)I.

premise: The Ampere force on a segment of wire carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = BIL.
conclusion: The force on AB is F_AB = (2/3)F.

premise: The Ampere force on a segment of wire carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = BIL.
conclusion: The force on AC is F_AC = (1/3)F.

premise: The Ampere force on a segment of wire carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = BIL.
conclusion: The force on CB is F_CB = (1/3)F.

premise: The forces F_AC and F_CB are equal in magnitude but act in directions that form an angle of 120Â° with each other.
conclusion: The resultant of these two forces is F_resultant = (1/3)F.

premise: The total resultant force is the sum of the force on AB and the resultant of the forces on AC and CB.
